posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
@23f1003128 @22f3001912 @KeshavMishra

I have checked the questions. And I am getting the answer within the expected range of options. There is nothing wrong with the question or the answer choices.

Regards

posts.name: JAI SUBIKSHA T
posts.cooked: You may have errors in grouping misspelled cities. use appropriate libraries like fuzzywuzzy to use phonetic clusters

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
Hi Jai,

Just to add on to your comment, another good tool to use is Openrefine which was discussed in the lecture video, because it has good inspection tools to quickly iterate and fix the spelling errors among other things. You can also use a multitude of different methodologies/algorithms within open refine to catch all the various edge cases and quickly tweak parameters of those algorithms in a nice gui.

Kind regards,

posts.name: Monica Vaze
posts.cooked:
One observation from OpenRefine clustering.
The cities ‘Dhaka’ and ‘Tokyo’ were being considered in the same cluster for me while using OpenRefine. If that case was not paid attention at, it must have misclustered Dhaka entries as Tokyo. And that can lead to different answers.

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
Yes you are right. Remember its not open refine but the algorithm that is causing it to happen. So it would happen even inside a python library that used the same algorithm but it would not be immediately evident and easily go unnoticed unless you were diligent about coding in some checks.

Whereas the advantage with a tool like open refine you can immediately spot the problem very quickly before it happens.
